author: walpole1720
body:
Yeah, the market is up over all and falling hard right now.  That’s generally pretty scary.  But there are a lot of sectors that are still looking good.  Semiconductors, for instance.  PE of 36, forward PE of 18.

I sold a crap load of puts on microchip companies today.  I’m hoping to get assigned at a deep discount next month and ride those suckers to the moon.

As far as cryptos go; this may be a bubble but I doubt it.  I think we are witnessing an S-curve and it’s still in the early adoption phase.

body: I did the unthinkable and bought new because the used car market has lost most of it's advantage.  People have caught up to the idea that buying slightly used vehicles with low mileage nets good savings... but since everyone is now doing that, it no longer holds true.  Quite surprised automakers haven't jacked the prices up on new, considering the microchip shortage and resulting supply shortage.

author: 4ppleF4n
body:
IBM is a hugely IP generator. They get issued more patents every year than any other company in the world -- over 9000 in 2020, which was nearly **50%** more than the second company, Samsung. And they've been the top patent company for almost the last 20 years.

They also just demonstrated the two-nanometer microchip -- leapfrogging every other company by at least 2 generations: https://www.cnn.com/2021/05/06/tech/ibm-semiconductor-two-nanometer/index.html

Toyota TM, very attractive value and bright future,  should have an outstanding quarter since they said they didn't expect major problems from microchip shortage like the other manufacturers did.  They have the best hybrid lineup right now, and lots more HEV, PHEV, in the pipeline,  BEV in 2025.  Best run company, possibly ever.

BK makes piles of cash,  usually buys back a lot of stock (significantly shrinking share count for years).  The Fed limited buybacks and dividend increases for all the Significant Financial Institutions,  even though they were/are in great shape. Fed handcuffs should be coming off next month and they plan on buying max amount allowed daily for the next year.

CHKP.  awesome cyber security company,  unknown and unloved (profitable tech company).   It's an Israeli company listed on NASDAQ,  25% insider owned, buys back a lot of stock.

author: ShittyStockPicker
body:
The microchip market itself is exploding with demand. Everything, I mean fucking everything is getting microchips now. Listen to the conference calls. All the chip manufacturers are building new foundries to handle the growth in demand.   


Long story short, people are finding more uses for AI, and better AI requires more powerful chips. Sure, the stock is trading at a high P/E. That doesn't mean it's not on my pullback radar.   


Value investing for me is all about buying and holding for 10+ years. I expect the demand for chips to power AI skyrocketing over the next 10 years. Self-driving cars, automated factories, airborne pizza delivery, robotic pilots, algorithms for predicting consumer behavior, automated logistics, personal health AI wearables, kill bots to dominate the battlefield. There are uses for AI that we still haven't found yet, and all of those new uses are going to require lots of chips.   


Even now, chip manufacturers are building new foundries to meet the demand. I'm so fucking bullish on chip manufacturing over the next 10 years. I'm thinking about switching out some of my VGT tech etf funds specifically to a semiconductor ETF to hold for the next 10 years.

author: ShittyStockPicker
body:
The microchip market itself is exploding with demand. Everything, I mean fucking everything is getting microchips now. Listen to the conference calls. All the chip manufacturers are building new foundries to handle the growth in demand.   


Long story short, people are finding more uses for AI, and better AI requires more powerful chips. Sure, the stock is trading at a high P/E. That doesn't mean it's not on my pullback radar.   


Value investing for me is all about buying and holding for 10+ years. I expect the demand for chips to power AI skyrocketing over the next 10 years. Self-driving cars, automated factories, airborne pizza delivery, robotic pilots, algorithms for predicting consumer behavior, automated logistics, personal health AI wearables, kill bots to dominate the battlefield. There are uses for AI that we still haven't found yet, and all of those new uses are going to require lots of chips.   


Even now, chip manufacturers are building new foundries to meet the demand. I'm so fucking bullish on chip manufacturing over the next 10 years. I'm thinking about switching out some of my VGT tech etf funds specifically to a semiconductor ETF to hold for the next 10 years.

author: Summebride
body:
It's actually not.  That's the biggest myth in the industry, created and indoctrinated by those who want you to think active participation and awareness are impossible and bad... and so you just close your eyes and trust them instead.  For a fee.  And if they fail, don't blame them, because... "You can't time the market!"

Notice that every bank, mogul, institution, fund, billionaire, millionaire, pension, sovereign, university, muni, hedge, family office, farmer, corporation, money manager, insurer on earth devotes most of their resources and personnel to spending 24x7x365 timing the market.  Yet they tell you "it doesn't work".

It's nonsense.  Even the lemmings who believe and spread it don't accept the myth in any other aspect of their existence.  They time the market looking for Black Friday sales.  They sell their house when the market is hot, and they try to buy a snow shovel in the spring when it goes on clearance.  The farmer keeps his crop in a silo waiting on the peak price, and the car buyer tries to grind for a better deal near month end when the dealer is supposedly more motivated.  When soup goes on sale, we buy a bunch of extra cans.  

Literally everything in our life is governed by "timing the market" yet we're supposed to believe it doesn't work when it comes to the actual, literal market?  

Hogwash.  

It was more than possible to time the market when Disney stock dropped under $80 and MSFT dipped to $130.  And it was pretty obvious when Palantir popped to $45 during the GME frenzy, it was appropriate to "time the market" and cash that in.

Timing the market absolutely does work.

author: michael_curdt
body:
2020 was pretty much free money. Please don’t get used to that. That said, I am really sorry to admit that your picks are below average at best. Stock picking is not for everybody, especially if you are new to the game. If I were you, I would sell them and pick up quality companies so I can sleep better at night. 

“What exactly should I buy?”

Why not the big tech? AAPL, AMZN, MSFT, FB. That’s a portfolio you will be proud of come rain or shine. 

“But those are boring household names. I want to pick somewhat riskier stuff in hopes of better returns.”

Even in this case, I suggest you diversify 60% of your portfolio in large companies with solid fundamentals and take meaningful risks with the remaining 40%. 

“I lost faith in individual stocks. It’s not my cup of tea”

Fine, roll with ETFs! SPY, QQQ, XLY, VNQ etc. They contain hundreds of good companies within them, so you will fall and rise with the market. Won’t be your fault anymore. 

Why not a mix of everything above? 

From your picks it appeared like you are into penny stocks. That’s a big no-no in my books. Don’t be afraid to purchase few shares of an expensive stock. You want to own good companies, not a lot of shares of junk. 

Just keep in mind that anything that goes up quickly will fall back as quickly. So don’t give into hype. Slow and steady will win you the race. 

That said, I am glad to see that you started investing at the age of 20. I wish I did that. Good days are ahead of you. All the best!

author: ThedanishDane
body:
Straigth out the gate, i'm honestly undecided/unsure on whether you or OP will end being right.   
However, the difference between now and 1999 is that the growth companies of today actually make money, and A LOT of it. Facebook, Apple, Microsoft, Amazon, Google and the likes have shown that they either are, or have proven that they can be, hugely profitable compared to essentially all other companies of the past.   
And because we have seen these examples, in the case of interest rate hikes, investors will be much more patient with their investments in "zombie-companies". I mean sure, several would collapse and we would see some retraction from specific companies like Wework, Uber and the like. I don't think interest rate hikes would cause the massive crash that many people seem to think.   


But i'm honestly conflicted, because i feel like there's some aspect to theories above that i haven't heard, or more likely don't understand. I'm also much more worried (from an investor standpoint) about government regulation as i feel a increasingly growing sentiment to regulate data privacy and to a lesser extent monopoly/oligopolies.

author: ChestyMenace
body: I'm not a cybersecurity expert, but I am a software engineer working for a Fortune 50 company, so I do have a little insight as it pertains to my job. To my knowledge, we do not use any of the products mentioned thus far. The only thing we do use related to this space would be Fastly, but I don't expect that to last. We have many dedicated teams that produce and create their own tools, phasing out the need for 3rd-party solutions. There is a ton of competition in this space and I'm not aware of anything that sets one apart from the other besides simple name recognition. Someone willing to do a lot more DD could easily refute me, but I don't believe any of these companies have much of a moat and even so, they are one failure away from dropping off a cliff. MSFT will survive the recent hack. SolarWinds maybe not so much. Shell, Kroger and a number of others were hacked, they will all survive, but the cyber security company Accelion who is responsible for the vulnerability, who knows. Cybersecurity investment comes with a lot of speculation, and I would caution you against investing in any of these companies long term.

author: DPX90
body:
I don't really want to argue your main point, but this made me laugh:

>...and the winners of the dot com crash , like Apple, Microsoft and Amazon, have outperformed everything...

I mean dude, you deliberately use survivorship bias as an argument. Like Petsdotcom, Webvan or even Cisco didn't exist.

Some of the really high quality companies like Google or Amazon will most likely not "collapse", they will either just correct or have very little returns if you buy them at their current prices. But even this is not sure. Cisco was and is a great company, yet it has never recovered to pre-dotcom levels, and you were in the red with Amazon too for like a decade if you bought at highs before the collapse.

For shittier companies that are valued to tens of billions of dollars without making a single dime of profit, there will be a rude awakening, or at least for their investors.

Addressing your last paragraph, I might be relying on "outdated financial discipline viewpoints", whatever the fuck that is (it sounds like you're essentially saying the "this time it's different" bs), but at least I'm not relying on hindsight bias and survivorship bias to formulate my models.

author: Broad_Remote499
body:
The concept of margin of safety involves having a margin between price and value in case your calculations of value are incorrect. For instance, if you see a company priced at $90 and you think it’s true value is $100, there’s not much margin of safety (if you were slightly off and it’s true value is actually $90 instead of $100, you aren’t getting a deal). On the other hand, a company priced at $10 which you see as worth $100 has a huge margin of safety. Even if you were off dramatically and it’s true value is $50, you have bought the company at a great price.

Price to book ratio uses tangible assets, which in the early 20th century America (think Ben Graham) was highly correlated with earning power due to the American economy being more industrial than it is today. Think of companies like Microsoft, Facebook, or Google which need relatively little tangible assets to generate revenues via online advertising, selling subscriptions, etc. Business value is generally accepted to be the present value of future cash flows, so the value of tangible assets today are very dependent on the industry in which a company operates.

The problem is trying to guess which companies are going to outperform 

a. your index funds

b. AAPL, MSFT, GOOG, etc

If you own something like VOO, AAPL is currently its largest holding at under 6%.  If AAPL stock goes on a run, VOO is going to rise considerably less than straight up owning AAPL.

The main question you need to ask yourself is if you think you can pick the next AAPL, GOOG, AMZN, MSFT, etc.  If the answer is yes, then it might be better to sell off your current positions in AAPL and MSFT and invest in those.  

In my opinion, AAPL and MSFT are very safe bets for the time being.  The market is really whacky right now and I would be hesitant to sell those in favor of some other small or mid cap stock that you hope might one day join the ranks of the big boys.

author: EvilUmpire
body:
Like FAANG alumni Netflix before it, I don't see Amazon lasting on this index. 

Like Netflix, there's nothing proprietary about what Amazon does. Everyone and anyone is creating their own online marketplaces, and if you haven't used Amazon lately, it's become a completely shit-pile of dodgy products and scam marketing.

2 years ago, 90% of my online purchases were with Amazon. Now? Maybe 50%.....I go direct to the seller, use Wal-Mart, use a Shopify enabled market, etc. 

Same goes for their cloud and streaming services.....nothing proprietary, just like Netflix. 

Google has the biggest moat in my opinion. It's not getting replaced anytime soon. 

Microsoft is #2 for me. It will forever be ingrained in 90% of business and personal computing.

Apple is #3. I am a tad concerned that so much of their revenue is derived from a single product, but their management is impressive. 

Facebook is #4, but is also the one I'm least certain about, one way or another. Their product seems to have become a bastion for bat-shit crazies. Basically, every uninformed person I know is a heavy facebook user.....completely roped into their local groups and trendy conspiracy theories. These people like their echo-chambers, so I suspect user retention, and trust in the platform, to remain high. However, as witnessed by TikTok, a younger generation could conceivably ditch fb in an instant for something more in tune with their zeitgeist.

author: RollThePoint
body: Lol, that's as helpful as saying sometimes stocks go up and sometimes they go down. From what I have read, dividends and value are what folks like during times of inflation and economic uncertainty. Warren buffet invests in value and it stands the test of time. Growth is basically what we have been in after the 2000 bubble recovery, pretty much big gains as the US shifted from industry to tech (Microsoft, apple, google, amazon leading the s&p 500 funds). Time in the market and time period trends are what matters here IMO. Long term/far from retirement = more risk/growth funds, short term during times of uncertainty/closer to retirement = value/dividends/cash. If you are not an active investor and are close to retiring value and dividend are attractive because risk is lower. Could be wrong though, I just read crap on the internet, lol.

author: F1shB0wl816
body:
I don’t think you understand people stop holding volatile assets when they don’t have the time to wait it out. You’re pretending people hold boomer stocks until they die, yet it’s widely agreed that it’s safer and smarter to invest more and more into bonds or the likes, than to have your money in volatile assets that could take a much bigger hit in the time frame you need it. That has nothing to do with believing or disbelieving in the market, that’s taking financial security seriously.

Just because you don’t have a reason to sell doesn’t mean you can speak for the mind of millions. After all, if you intend to enjoy the fruits of your investments, you sell. 

That’s not the difference between investing and trading. You just come across like a smart ass, implying meanings where there are none. Investing and trading aren’t mutually exclusive, you can have both, one or neither. There’s no hard rule like you’re stating. 

I never stated what the major players are doing. I’m sensible and don’t speak for millions on data that doesn’t exist because I feel some type of way. The burden of proof falls on those who are making the claim, which is you, me asking for proof is not me arguing for opposite. It’s me arguing to back up your point with facts which you don’t have. 

Everything you state is like it’s some black and white opinion. Everything has to be this or that. Numbers don’t speak for beliefs. But what do I expect from someone who doesn’t understand volatility and that sometimes people need to protect themselves from the risk of loss. That volatile investments make for better short term trades, just as you always see volumes spike on massive volatility movements. When Microsoft starts going 20% in a night, than see if your statement holds true. Look at any volatile asset and look at its comparable trade volume. Btc has rose more than 10x Microsoft the past 3 months, if you want short term or big gains, where’s your better chance? And ones beliefs have nothing to do with capitalizing on cryptos appreciation. 

Funny how you think you’re educating anyone, but you lacked the knowledge to know you don’t invest money you need immediately and was to worried about buying at the wrong time because you have no apparent ability to do an research on what you could guesstimate to be a fair price and target. From someone who infers useless data to go on about points they know nothing about, while not even understand the concept of volatility and millions of reasons why one could realize gains. 

Have a good one. I’ll smack my head on the wall before I give you anymore time out of my day. I proved my point and that was that you couldn’t back shit. The very fear mongering, fud I speak of that’s nothing more than someone’s else ignorant opinion.

author: kids_eat_drugs
body:
Hey,

Got a question regarding 401k vs personal portfolio allocations. My 401k investments go into a few index funds, mainly in tech / mid cap companies / consumer staples / etc. At the moment, my personal RobinHood portfolio has positions in overlapping companies like AAPL, MSFT. I’m wondering if it would be a wise idea to do something like this

•	⁠sell my overlapping stock positions in my RobinHood portfolio and use the equity gained to invest in growth stocks that aren’t in my 401k funds.
•	⁠up my 401k contribution since I’m only doing 4% which my employer then matches with a specific percentage

I just feel like it’s somewhat dumb to invest in overlapping companies in two accounts. I might as well buy them only in the 401k since I’m not even taxed there whereas my salary gets taxed before I can load funds into RobinHood. What do you guys think?
